cs.man.ac.uk.classifier

Class GHVFDT

  • java.lang.Object
    • cs.man.ac.uk.classifier.Classifier
      • cs.man.ac.uk.classifier.GHVFDT
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Tree

    public class GHVFDT
extends Classifier
implements Tree

    Gaussian-Hellinger Very Fast Decision Tree (GH-VFDT). A Hoeffding tree is an incremental, any-time decision tree induction algorithm that is capable of learning from massive data streams, assuming that the distribution generating examples does not change over time. Hoeffding trees exploit the fact that a small sample can often be enough to choose an optimal splitting attribute. This idea is supported mathematically by the Hoeffding bound, which quantifies the number of observations (in our case, examples) needed to estimate some statistics within a prescribed precision (in our case, the goodness of an attribute).

    A theoretically appealing feature of Hoeffding Trees not shared by other incremental decision tree learners is that it has sound guarantees of performance. Using the Hoeffding bound one can show that its output is asymptotically nearly identical to that of a non-incremental learner using infinitely many examples. The GH-VFDT utilizes a decision tree split criterion designed to improve minority class recall rates on imbalanced data streams, i.e. those streams where the class distribution is worse than 1:100. See the following for details:

    This implementation is built upon the Hoeffding Tree provided in MOA, thus a great deal of credit goes to the MOA team for their initial implementation and library. We greatly acknowledge their efforts. Though this version of the algorithm is a complete re-write, and thus not compatible with WEKA or MOA, since it it intended for stand-alone use and study.

    For more details of the algorithm see,

    R. J. Lyon, J. M. Brooke, J. D. Knowles, B. W. Stappers. Hellinger Distance Trees for Imbalanced Streams In 22nd International Conference on Pattern Recognition, pages 1969-1974, Stockholm, Sweden, 2014. IEEE.

    For details of the original VFDT model, see:

    G. Hulten, L. Spencer, and P. Domingos. Mining time-changing data streams. In KDDâ€™01, pages 97-106, San Francisco, CA, 2001. ACM Press.

    Parameters:

    • The number of instances a leaf should observe between split attempts
    • The allowable error in split decision, values closer to 0 will take longer to decide
    • Threshold below which a split will be forced to break ties
    • Only allow binary splits

    Acknowledgments

    This work was supported by grant EP/I028099/1 for the University of Manchester Centre for Doctoral Training in Computer Science, from the UK Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC).

    Author:
    Rob Lyon

      • split

        public void split(ActiveLearningNode node,
                  SplitNode parent,
                  int parentIndex)
        Methods which determines the optimal split point. Uses the Gaussian approximation of the Hellinger distance to measure the distance between the positive and negative class for a given split point.
        Specified by:
        split in interface Tree
        Parameters:
        node - the current node to split, if possible.
        parent - the parent of node.
        parentIndex - the index of the node in the parent, corresponding to which branch of the parent it belongs to.

      • newLearningNode

        public LearningNode newLearningNode()
        Specified by:
        newLearningNode in interface Tree
        Returns:

      • newLearningNode

        public LearningNode newLearningNode(double[] initialClassObservations)
        Specified by:
        newLearningNode in interface Tree
        Parameters:
        initialClassObservations - the class distributions used to initialize the node, and used for making predictions. The class distribution is stored in a double array, such that each element in the array contains the total count of examples for a specific class. For example initialClassObservations = [ 10 , 45 ] using zero indexing indicates there are 10 members of class zero, and 45 of class one.
        Returns:
        a new learning node capable of making predictions.

        Description copied from interface: Tree
        Finds the learning nodes recursively, starting at the specified node. Found nodes are not returned directly, rather they are appended to the List object passed in to this method.

        parent - of the node to search from, a split point node.
        parentBranch - the index of the node being activated, in the parent, corresponding to which branch of the parent it belongs to.
